instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00239: What is 820-00239? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.PP3V3_G3H: What is PP3V3_G3H? PP3V3_G3H is a 3.3v power line that is present when the machine is in a Global System Hardware Off state, and should come on before most other rails so that the USB-C circuitry can be powered for the charger.
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H: What is PPDCIN_G3H? PPDCIN_G3H Is a power rail that comes directly from the laptop charger..
definitions.PP3V0_G3H: What is PP3V0_G3H? PP3V0_G3H is a 3.0v power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state..
definitions.PPVCC_S0_CPU: What is PPVCC_S0_CPU? The "PPVCC_S0_CPU" power rail is responsible for supplying power to the CPU when the MacBook is fully on, or in the S0 state. This rail is one of the main voltages that the CPU requires for operation. .
definitions.SMC_LID: What is SMC_LID? SMC_LID tells the machine the system is open when it is 3.3v to 3.4v, and closed when it is low such as 0v-0.6v. When this signal is low, the machine may go to sleep or have no backlight. .
definitions.SMC_LID_LEFT: What is SMC_LID_LEFT? SMC_LID_LEFT is a signal that tells the system if the lid is closed from the left LID sensor. If it is low, the system thinks the lid is closed – if it is 3.3v, the system thinks the machine is open. SMC_LID_LEFT needs to be high for the machine to stay awake and have a backlight. .
definitions.SMC_LID_RIGHT: What is SMC_LID_RIGHT? SMC_LID_RIGHT is a signal that tells the system if the lid is closed from the right LID sensor. If it is low, the system thinks the lid is closed – if it is 3.3v, the system thinks the machine is open. SMC_LID_RIGHT needs to be high for the machine to stay awake and have a backlight. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No video on panel or external monitor
threads.message:
Hi all.
First, I'm not familiar with working on this model board.

No video on internal panel or externally on any USB C port with a USB-HDMI adaptor that I've had working in other Macbooks.
No fans, no chime.

No signs of any liquid damage on either side of board.

Power rails seem good, CPU gets hot, USB hard disk gets flashing light on it.
Tried with another AC adaptor, both with and without battery connected.
Tried SMC reset.
Tried on external panel with internal disconnected, and tried other internal panels.

<SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL> IS 22v.
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>HS_CPU</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>HS_OTH5V</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>HS_OTH3V3</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>S4_HS_TPAD</SIGNAL> are all 14.v.
<SIGNAL>PP3V0_G3H</SIGNAL> IS 3.4v.
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>, S5, SUS all 3.7v.
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL>, S4, S0 all 5.7v.

Any suggestions appreciated. 
Thanks.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No video on panel or external monitor
threads.message:
Seems to have low battery on your multimeter.
Change it and post CPU core voltage when you get flashing USB device.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No video on panel or external monitor
threads.message:
lol, good diagnosis there 2informaticos in regards to the  low battery on my multimeter!

OK, after replacing the battery in it, here's the CPU core voltage:
When I press the power button, about 3 seconds later, <SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> goes from 0.0v up to 1.14v
About 3 seconds later, that voltage drops down to 0.71.
And then seems to remain there.

When I plug in the USB memory stick with a light on it, and when its flashing, the voltage is the same,0.71 volts.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No video on panel or external monitor
threads.message: Disconnect internal LCD, to force external video.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No video on panel or external monitor
threads.message:
I had tried disconnecting internal LCD, but still no external on any of the USBC ports.
I retested, on all 4 USBC ports, with two different USBC-HDMI adapters that we use regularly on other macbooks.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No video on panel or external monitor
threads.message:
Missing internal/external video at same time points to graphics issue.
Unfortunately, this board doesn't have dedicated (discrete) GPU; so should be iGPU problem.
Check diode mode to ground on all <SIGNAL>EDP_INT</SIGNAL> data lines of J8500.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No video on panel or external monitor
threads.message:
OK.
That makes sense.
Thanks again for your help.

With the screen disconnected, red lead to ground, all seem to read around 256:
Diode mode to ground readings:

<SIGNAL>EDP_INT_AUX_N</SIGNAL> 254
<SIGNAL>EDP_INT_AUX_P</SIGNAL> 257
<SIGNAL>EDP_INT_ML_N</SIGNAL><0> 256
<SIGNAL>EDP_INT_ML_P</SIGNAL><0> 257
<SIGNAL>EDP_INT_ML_N</SIGNAL><1> 255
<SIGNAL>EDP_INT_ML_P</SIGNAL><1> 256
<SIGNAL>EDP_INT_ML_N</SIGNAL><2> 257
<SIGNAL>EDP_INT_ML_P</SIGNAL><2> 258
<SIGNAL>EDP_INT_ML_N</SIGNAL><3> 255
<SIGNAL>EDP_INT_ML_P</SIGNAL><3> 256

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No video on panel or external monitor
threads.message:
Not sure if CPU core should remain at 0.7V or should drop to 0.6V.
If you get USB flashibg, board looks to work.
Caps Lock light reacts too?
The chime comes back after PRAM reset?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No video on panel or external monitor
threads.message:
Hi again.
I rechecked CPU core - goes to 0.69v then stays there.
I get USB light flashing on all 4 USBC ports.
Yes, Capslock light works correctly.
Touchpad does tap correctly when unit is turned on.

NO Chime after PRAM reset - no chime, ever.
No fans, ever.

The macbook appears as a disk correctly when I put it in target disk mode.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No video on panel or external monitor
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No video on panel or external monitor
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No video on panel or external monitor
threads.message:
Then should be bad CPU (iGPU).
Just in case, try known good BIOS.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No video on panel or external monitor
threads.message:
Thanks again 2informaticos.
I only have a CH341A programmer, with a standard 8 pin SOIC adapter.
To load a good BIOS, do you have to manually solder wires to the board, or is their an adapter I can just plug in?
Never programmed a Mac BIOS before.

And, given I can get the unit to boot in Target disk mode, can you flash the BIOS via target disk mode, using Apple Configurator, or by some other means?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No video on panel or external monitor
threads.message:
If you plan to stay in business with Apple boards, buy Medusa programmer; with necessary set of adapters.
Other programmers able to connect directly to J6100 are available to buy also.
Years ago I posted fotos about how to solder WSON chip on small SOP-DIP adapter which comes with classic adapters (like CH341).
